Fig. 1 XRD patterns of (a) the fresh and (b) the aged samples of Cu-SSZ-13, 0.075Ce-Cu, 0.075Ce0.15Zr-Cu, 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu, 0.075Ce0.35Zr-Cu, and 0.075Ce0.45Zr-Cu. (c) Crystalline intensity and the reduction rate of crystallinity of the serial aged samples compared with their corresponding fresh ones. Fig 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of (a) Cu-SSZ-13-F (b) Cu-SSZ-13-A (c) 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-F (d) 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A (e) 0.075Ce0.35Zr-Cu-F and (f) 0.075Ce0.35Zr-Cu-A. Fig 2 Fig. 3 NH3-TPD results of the fresh (a) and the aged (b) catalysts. (c) The total acid amounts of the fresh and aged catalysts based on the NH3-TPD patterns. Fig 3 Fig. 4 The H2-TPR profiles of the fresh (a) and the aged catalysts (b). (c) The proportions of different Cu species in Cu-SSZ-13-A, 0.075Ce-Cu-A and 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A. Fig 4 Fig. 5 EPR results of dehydrated fresh and aged samples. Fig 5 Fig. 6 The NH3-SCR activity curves as a function of temperature over the fresh and aged catalysts. (a) deNOx activity over fresh XCe-Cu and Cu-SSZ-13; (b) deNOx activity over 800 °C aged XCe-Cu and Cu-SSZ-13; (c) deNOx activity over fresh 0.075CeYZr-Cu and 0.075Ce-Cu; (d) deNOx activity over 800 °C aged 0.075CeYZr-Cu, 0.075Ce-Cu and Cu-SSZ-13. Reaction condition: 500 ppm NO, NH3/NO = 1, 5 vol.% O2, 10 vol.% H2O, with N2 as the balance, GHSV = 120, 000 h−1. Fig 6 Fig. 7 The Arrhenius plots of the NOx conversion rate constants, calculated from data between 100 and 140°C. The apparent activation energies obtained from the regression over Cu-SSZ-13-F, Cu-SSZ-13-A, 0.075Ce-Cu-F, 0.075Ce-Cu-A, 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-F, and 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A were 37.53 kJ/mol, 50.51 kJ/mol, 35.11 kJ/mol, 45.19 kJ/mol, 31.90 kJ/mol, and 40.64 kJ/mol, respectively. Fig 7 Fig. 8 DRIFT spectra for NH3 (500 ppm) adsorption on (a) 0.075Ce-Cu-F (b) 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-F (c) 0.075Ce-Cu-A (d) 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A at 175 °C. Fig 8 Fig. 9 DRIFT spectra of NO + O2 reacted with ad-NH3 species over: (a) 0.075Ce-Cu-F (b) 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-F (c) 0.075Ce-Cu-A and (d) 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A at 175°C. Fig 9 Fig. 10 Variation of the accumulation amount of NH4NO3 (1448cm−1) over 0.075Ce-Cu-A and 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A with reaction time. Understanding the roles of Ce and Zr on a Ce-Zr/Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst with improved hydrothermal stability for NOx reduction by NH3 Wubo Fan Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Formal analysis a Rongjiao Xia Methodology Investigation a Fen Zhou Methodology Investigation a Yuan Li Methodology a Ganxue Wu Methodology Formal analysis Conceptualization b ⁎ Yaoqiang Chen Supervision Conceptualization c Jianli Wang Supervision Conceptualization c Juan Liang Supervision Formal analysis Conceptualization b ⁎ Wenyan Zhao Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Formal analysis Conceptualization a ⁎ a Sichuan Institute of Ecology and Environment Science, Chengdu, Sichuan, China Sichuan Institute of Ecology and Environment Science Chengdu Sichuan China aSichuan Institute of Ecology and Environment Science, Chengdu, Sichuan, China b College of Architecture and Environment, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, China College of Architecture and Environment Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan China bCollege of Architecture and Environment, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, China c College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, China College of Chemistry Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan China cCollege of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Sichuan Institute of Ecology and Environment Science, Chengdu, Sichuan, China. Sichuan Institute of Ecology and Environment Science Chengdu Sichuan China Promotion of the hydrothermal stability of Cu-CHA catalyst is a huge challenge. Metal modification is one of the important methods to improve the hydrothermal stability of Cu-CHA, but deeply insight into the roles of doped metal during the hydrothermal process is still lacking. In this study, a Ce-Zr/Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst was designed, and its robustness was significantly enhanced by adjusting the Ce and Zr doping ratios compared to Cu-SSZ-13. It was found that introducing a certain amount of Ce into Cu-SSZ-13 could enhance the redox property and stabilizing the framework structure. Nevertheless, the ability of Ce to stabilize the framework was still limited because the structure would be severely damaged during hydrothermal aging due to the movement of CuOx clusters generated in the cage. But, interestingly, an appropriate Ce-Zr co-doping could generate new hydroxyl components and acid sites, and inhibit the migration and agglomeration of isolated Cu ions during hydrothermal aging, which could significantly alleviate the formation of CuOx and CuAl2O4 species, thus promoting the stability of the as-gained catalyst. Additionally, an appropriate Ce-Zr co-doping could also restrain the accumulation of intermediate product NH4NO3 in the low temperature NH3-SCR reaction after hydrothermal aging, resulting in an enhanced low-temperature SCR ability over the aged catalyst. This work can be used to assist in the design of the high-efficient diesel Cu-CHA catalyst, thus highlighting its remarkable potential for industrial applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CeZr/Cu-SSZ-13 NH3-SCR Hydrothermal stability NH4NO3 aggregation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Ammonia Selective Catalytic Reduction (NH3-SCR) is currently recognized as one of the most promising methods of NOx abatement for diesel vehicles due to its better fuel economy and great NOx conversion activity [1]. For the diesel SCR technology, Cu-exchanged small-pore zeolite (Cu-CHA) is an important technological breakthrough in the past 20 years, due to its excellent catalytic activity and good hydrothermal stability [2,3]. For instance, Cu/SSZ-13 can maintain more than 90% NOx removal efficiency with GHSV at 40, 000 h−1 in a wide temperature range of 200-450 °C even after aging at 760 °C for 20 h, the unique advantage induced to be commercialized on a large scale around 2017 [4]. However, in the real-world diesel vehicle application systems, the diesel particulate filter (DPF) placed in front of the SCR unit enables the SCR unit to face a high temperature even as high as 800 °C and ca. 7% H2O when the DPF unit is regenerated periodically. Under such a severe hydrothermal aging condition, the traditional Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst would still suffer a significant performance deactivate due to the dealumination and structural collapse. Therefore, promoting the robustness of Cu-SSZ-13 is essential and meaningful to address the scientific bottleneck in the actual application [5,6]. Up to now, although many experimental and theoretical research efforts have been devoted, enhancing the resistance ability to hydrothermal aging remains a huge challenge. In general, the hydrothermal deactivation of Cu-SSZ-13 can be summarized from two aspects: 1) the reduced acidity and redox property derived from the dealumination; 2) the formation of inactive CuOx clusters and CuAlOx species resulted from the migration and aggregation of active Cu species during hydrothermal aging. During the hydrothermal aging process, a part of Cu2+ and Cu+ will change their location and transform into CuOx clusters, especially the isolated Cu2+ close to the 8-member ring (8MR), which not only collapses the structure, but also acts as active sites for the NH3 oxidation reaction at high temperature, thereby inhibiting the high temperature SCR activity [7–10]. So stabilization of active Cu species aimed to alleviating the formation of CuOx clusters is key for breaking through the limitations of the unsatisfactory hydrothermal stability of Cu-SSZ-13. In the past decade, rare earth metal modification via protecting the framework Al from dealumination is recognized as an efficient strategy to improve the stability of zeolite-based catalysts [5,6,11,12]. For examples, Gao et al. [13] proposed that the accumulation of detrimental aggregated Cu species (i.e., CuOx clusters) can be hindered by introducing some additives that can trap CuOx. Ce, as a relatively cheap and nontoxic rare earth metal element, is usually used as active component or additives in the supported catalysts [14–18]. Due to the alternation of valence states (Ce3+→Ce4+), it is generally believable that Ce modification can stabilize the active sites of Cu-CHA catalyst (Table S1). For instance, Usui et al. [19] believed that introducing a small amount of Ce to Cu-SSZ-13 could stabilize the framework of SSZ-13, consequently increasing the stability of the catalyst. Wang et al. [20] proposed that Ce doping could stabilize the Cu active centers of Cu/SSZ-13 and suppress the dealumination during hydrothermal aging. Therefore, Ce may be an appropriate additive to stabilizing the CHA zeolite framework during the hydrothermal aging process. Additionally, Zirconia is a well-known promoter of metal-based catalysts, and also acts as a phase stabilizer to facilitate the dispersion and stability of active metal through inducing a strong metal-support interaction [21,22]. Numerous studies have verified that Zr doping is also beneficial to boost the durability of zeolite-based catalyst [23–26]. For instance, Peng et al. [23] believed that ZrO2 could act as such a CuO "trap", forming a stable crystalline phase with CuOx, alleviating the negative effect of CuOx clusters on the zeolite framework structure, and consequently suppressing the non-selected ammonia oxidation reaction. Bin et al. [24] reported that the addition of Zr could improve the dispersion of active Cu species over the Zr-doped Cu-ZSM-5 catalyst. In addition, Chen et al. [25] found that some new hydroxyl groups and Lewis acid sites were generated after introducing an appropriate amount of Zr into Fe-SSZ-13, which fostered the formation of reaction intermediates such as -NH2, -HNO2, -NO2, etc., and consequently accelerated the SCR reaction. Therefore, Zr doping has been verfied as an effective method to improve the hydrothermal stability of zeolite-based catalyst. Although single metal modification on the structure and denitrification performance of Cu-CHA has been wildly investigated, there is still a severe lack of the deep insight into the roles of bimetallic (such as co-doping of Ce and Zr) in the same SCR catalyst for the resistance to severe hydrothermal aging. It is worth noting that understanding the influence mechanism of bimetallic co-doping on the structure and catalytic performance before and after hydrothermal aging is one of the core interests for the rational designing high-efficient diesel Cu-CHA based SCR catalyst. In this work, a novel bimetallic doping SCR catalyst (Ce-Zr/Cu-SSZ-13) was designed in order to elucidate the influence of doped metals on the Cu coordination environments and zeolite framework during the hydrothermal aging. Firstly, a series of Ce\Zr doped Cu-SSZ-13 were synthesized by adjusting Ce/Zr atomic ratios. Then multiple characterization techniques including XRD, SEM, BET, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, EPR, and in situ DRIFTS were employed to investigate the roles of Ce and Zr, and clarify the promoting mechanism of Ce and Zr doping on the robustness of Cu-SSZ-13. This work may provide new opportunities for designing high-efficient SCR catalysts with great potential for application in the diesel NOx purification. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst preparation The commercial H-SSZ-13 with Si/Al∼11 was provided by an industrial supplier (Kaili Environmental Protection Co., Ltd). Before the metals modification, place the purchased H-SSZ-13 in a 105 °C oven overnight to remove excess water. It is noteworthy that the order of metal modification has a significant impact on catalytic activity (Fig. S1). After the optimization, Ce and Cu were modified on H-SSZ-13 zeolite via the wet exchange, and Zr modifiaction is performed through impregnation method. Firstly, the dried H-SSZ-13 was exchanged with 0.035, 0.05, 0.075, and 0.1M Ce(NO3)3·6H2O solutions at 80 °C for 5 h, respectively. The samples were then washed and dried to obtain Ce modificated SSZ-13. The as-prepared Ce-SSZ-13 was then exchanged with 0.15 M Cu(NO3)2 at 80 °C for 6 h. The obtained samples were washed and dried, and then calcined in a tube furnace at 550 °C for 5 h to obtain fresh Ce/Cu-SSZ-13. The obtained samples were named as XCe-Cu-F, where X represents different Ce(NO3)3·6H2O concentrations, and F suffix ‘-fresh’ represented the fresh catalysts. Ce-Zr/Cu-SSZ-13 was impregnated with Zr (NO3)4·5H2O as precursor to load Zr on XCe/Cu-SSZ-13, the mass fraction of Zr was 0.15%, 0.25%, 0.35%, and 0.45%, respectively. After drying, the samples were calcined at 550 °C for 5 h to obtain fresh Ce-Zr/Cu-SSZ-13. The obtained sample was named as XCeYZr-Cu-F, where Y represents the content of Zr in Ce-Zr/Cu-SSZ-13. 2.2 Hydrothermal aging treatment In order to explore the hydrothermal stability of the as-gained Ce/Zr doping Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts, a severe hydrothermal aging condition (800 °C for 16 h with 10% H2O/air) was employed. The aged XCe/Cu-SSZ-13 and Ce-Zr/Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts were denoted as XCe-Cu-A and XCeYZr-Cu-A, respectively. A suffix ‘-aged’ represented the aged catalysts. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The physico-chemical properties of the serial fresh and aged XCeYZr-Cu samples were characterized by various techniques including XRD, BET, SEM, ICP-AES, EPR, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and in situ DRIFTS. The details of the characterization are displayed in the supplementary information file. 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation The NH3-SCR catalytic activity was evaluated using a fixed-bed reactor. The detail of the evaluation condition characterization is described in the supplementary information file. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural properties In order to probe the influence of Zr and Ce doping on the structures and morphologies of the as-synthesized catalysts, XRD, N2 adsorption/desorption, and SEM measurements were employed. As is shown in Fig. 1(a) and (b), the characteristic peaks of fresh and aged Cu-SSZ-13, 0.075Ce-Cu and the serial 0.075CuYZr-Cu at 2θ = 13.1, 16.3, 18.1, 20.9, 25.3, 26.4 and 31.1 are well consistent with the standard CHA structure (PDF#52–0784) [26]. But the characteristic peaks of CuO (PDF#48-1548), CeO2 (PDF#34-0394) and ZrO2 (PDF#49-1642) were not detected in the XRD patterns, indicating that Cu, Ce and Zr are finely dispersed, or the particle size is not within the detection range of XRD [20]. Introducing a certain amount of Ce and Zr resulted in an insignificant drop of crystallinity (Fig. 1(c)), which may be attributed to the exchange of Ce to cationic sites to make up a small amount of defects of SSZ-13 [19,20]. Regardless, after hydrothermal aging, the crystallinity of the serial catalysts was significantly affected. Specifically, the reduction ratio of crystallinity over Cu-SSZ-13 and 0.075Ce-Cu was 42% and 32%, respectively, suggesting that an appropriate amount of Ce doping can slightly stabilize the zeolite framework of Cu-SSZ-13. Additionally, after further doping Zr, the reduction ratio of crystallinity over 0.075Ce0.15Zr-Cu, 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu, 0.075Ce0.35Zr-Cu, and 0.075Ce0.45Zr-Cu was 10%, 6%, 40% and 44%, respectively, which may be attributed to the strong interaction between Zr species and the zeolite framework or the slight dealumination of the zeolite framework. Based on these results, it is reasonable to speculate that appropriate Ce/Zr co-doping can significantly stabilize the zeolite framework structure of Cu-SSZ-13. Fig. 2 shows the SEM images of the serial fresh and aged samples. It can be clearly observed that it still maintained a regular hexahedron structural morphology after the introduction of Ce and Zr, indicating that the co-doping of Ce and Zr has little impact on the CHA hexahedron morphology, which is consistent with the XRD patterns. After severe hydrothermal aging at 800 °C for 16 h, as shown in Fig. S2, the average particle size of the sample Cu-SSZ-13 decreased from 4.14 to 3.94 µm compared with its corresponding fresh catalyst, indicator of a relatively obvious CHA structural collapse. Interestingly, the values of 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu slightly increases from 3.98 to 4.11µm. And increasing the Zr doping ratio resulted in a significant decrease in average particle size for both the fresh and aged samples compared with the Cu-CHA. These results suggest that the co-doping of Ce and Zr can effectively stabilize the CHA skeleton structure during the hydrothermal aging. Combining the XRD and SEM results, it can be concluded that an appropriate Ce/Zr doping is beneficial to improve the hydrothermal stability of the Cu-SSZ-13 based SCR catalyst, while an excess of Zr doping will lead to an opposite effect. The elemental compositions of the serial catalysts are summarized in Table S2. With the increase of Ce doping ratio, the Cu loading decreased to different degrees, and 0.1Ce-Cu-F has the least value among them. And introducing a small amount of Zr into the 0.075Ce-Cu-F had little impact on the Cu loading, but excessive Zr doping would slightly reduce the Cu loading, which is detrimental to the SCR activity. Table 1 summarizes the pore structural parameters of the serial fresh and aged samples. Compared with Cu-SSZ-13-F, the BET surface area, micropore area and pore volume of 0.075Ce-Cu-F and 0.075Ce0.15Zr-Cu-F were all reduced to a certain extent, which may be attributed to the blockage of part of the pores with the introduction of Ce and Zr. As predicted, after severe hydrothermal aging at 800 °C for 16 h, the three pore structural parameters were all reduced compared with their corresponding fresh samples, but the deterioration over 0.075Ce-Cu, 0.75Ce0.15Zr-Cu and 0.75Ce0.25Zr-Cu was significantly lower than that of Cu-SSZ-13, underscoring that Ce and Zr doping adopted can alleviate the collapse of the zeolite framework during the hydrothermal aging to a certain extent. To clarify the relationship between the Ce/Zr doping ratios and structures over the serial fresh and aged catalysts, three sets of samples, including the Cu-SSZ-13, 0.075Ce-Cu and 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu, were identified for further study. 3.2 Physical and chemical properties 3.2.1 Acidities To explore the effect of Ce and Zr doping on acidity, NH3-TPD experiments were carried out. As is shown in Fig. 3(a) , three types of NH3 desorption peaks could be fitted for all of these samples. According to the previous studies [27–29], the low-temperature desorption peak at around 280 °C is attributed to weakly adsorbed NH3 on extra-framework Al Lewis sites or physically adsorbed NH3. The medium-temperature peak is ascribed to the desorption from strong acid sites, mostly derived from the Cu2+ species on the exchanging sites [30]. The high-temperature peak at around 625 °C is corresponded to NH3 adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites [31]. With the introduction of Ce, both the strong L-acids and B-acids were reduced to some extent, which may be attributed to Ce occupying part of the ion exchange sites within the cage, slightly reducing the isolated Cu2+, as proved by the below EPR results. In any case, the desorption peak area at low temperature after Ce modification was significantly increased, meaning that Ce doping enhanced the surface adsorption capacity and weakened L acidity of the as-synthesized catalysts, which is beneficial to its low-temperature catalytic activity [32]. Interestingly, the desorption peak area of strong L-acid and B-acid increased significantly after doping a certain amount of Zr, which may be due to the generation of -OH groups (Zr-OH) and Lewis acid sites (like ZrOx, Zr4+) [24]. As is displayed in Fig. 3(b) and (c), after hydrothermal aging, a significant deterioration of B acid sites and strong L acid sites can be observed over Cu-SSZ-13, which may be due to the reason that part of the zeolite framework structure was damaged significantly. In comparison, the B-acid over 0.075Ce-Cu was only partially lost after hydrothermal aging, signifying that Ce doping can enhance the structural stability of Cu-SSZ-13 to some extent, which is also supported by the above XRD and SEM results. In addition, it is interesting that the amount of L acid associated with Cu2+ over 0.075Ce-Cu increased after aging compared with its corresponding fresh sample, which may be attributed to the transformation of Cu species during hydrothermal aging [7,8,33]. However, the sample 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu lost a large amount of B acid sites after hydrothermal aging, which may be due to the reason that some B acidic sites would be covered by the formed ZrO2-CuOx species deprived from the interaction between ZrO2 and Cu2+/Cu+. But no matter what, 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu still has a relatively larger amount of acid sites and the loss of acid content caused by hydrothermal aging is relatively smaller compared with the others. To sum up, an appropriate Ce/Zr co-doping is beneficial to the formation and stabilization of acid sites on the catalyst surface. 3.2.2 H2-TPR results H2-TPR measurement was performed to clarify the redox properties of the serial catalysts (Fig. 4(a) and (b)). The main two reduction peaks at 250 °C and 550 °C on Cu-SSZ-13-F and 0.075Ce-Cu-F samples are attributed to the reduction of isolated Cu2+ in the cage to Cu+ and Cu+ to Cu0, respectively [34–36]. It was found the reduction peak for Cu+ to Cu0 over 0.075Ce-Cu-F shifted to a higher temperature at 555 °C compared to 540 °C for Cu-SSZ-13-F, which may be attributed to the stabilizing effect of Ce on the isolated Cu2+ [13]. And the reduction peak for Cu2+ to Cu+ shifted to a lower temperature, indicating that the introduction of a small amount of Ce can enhance the redox property. After further introducing Zr into 0.075Ce-Cu, the peak areas of H2 consumption at low temperature are significantly reduced, and some other new peaks at 440 °C and 760 °C appear. According to previous reports [23,24,37], the H2 reduction peak at 440 °C can be assigned to the incorporation of the 6-MR Cu2+ into the ZrO2 phase to form ZrO2-CuOx species with a coordinating and oxygen-covered surface structure, and the ZrO2-CuOx species were coordinatively unsaturated, which would increase the mobility of active oxygen and thus boost the redox property. And the peak at 760 °C related to the reduction of Cu+ to Cu0 is partly derived from the reduction of isolated Cu2+ species and the automatic reduction of Cu(OH)+ during the dehydration process [19,36,38]. Additionally, two coordination sites of Cu+ ions coexist in the CHA structure [19,36,39] : one is located at the center of the hexagonal prism, and the other is located at the position entering the CHA cage from 6MR. Due to the steric hindrance effect, the reduction temperature of Cu+ ions at the center of the hexagonal prism is much higher than that of Cu+ ions near the 6MR [40]. Therefore, it is reasonable to speculate that the peaks between 450 and 600 °C are assigned to the reduction of Cu+ sites near the 6MR, while the highest peak above 700 °C refers to the reduction of Cu+ located in the center of the hexagonal prism. Based on the above analysis, it can be concluded that co-doping of Ce and Zr can fortify the production of more stable Cu2+ and Cu+ species. Gao et al. [13] believes that the presence of Cu2+/Cu+ redox cycling is conducive to SCR reaction. In order to further evaluate the effect of severe hydrothermal aging on the Cu coordination environment, H2-TPR was also performed for the aged samples. It can be seen from Fig. 4(b) that the a, b, c, d, e peaks associated with Cu species appear between 200-750°C, which can be attributed to the reduction of 8RM Cu2+, CuOx, 6RM Cu2+, CuAl2O4, and Cu+, respectively. And there are fewer isolated Cu2+, but more CuOx and CuAl2O4 species in Cu-SSZ-13-A, implying that its structure was significantly damaged after hydrothermal aging. As is displayed in Table S3, compared with Cu-SSZ-13-A, the H2 consumption amounts significantly reduced after doping Ce, suggesting that the structure damage can be alleviated via Ce doping, which is also supported by the XRD and NH3-TPD results. Additionally, it can be observed from Fig. 4(c) that 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A had a larger proportion of isolated Cu2+ and less CuOx species than 0.075Ce-Cu-A, meaning that continuously introducing an appropriate amount of Zr into 0.075Ce-Cu can further alleviate the formation of CuOx and CuAl2O4 species during the hydrothermal aging. Based on the above analysis, it can be speculated that appropriate Ce/Zr co-doping can increase the dispersion of Cu species and alleviate the aggregation of Cu species to produce CuOx and CuAl2O4 species. Furthermore, the H2 reduction peak at 440 °C associated with the 6RM Cu2+ (ZrO2 combined) still maintains good stability even after severe hydrothermal aging, further illustrating that there may be a strong interaction between ZrO2, active Cu species and zeolite framework. Interestingly, compared with 0.075Ce-Cu-A, all of the H2 reduction peaks of 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A shift to lower temperature, suggesting that an appropriate Zr doping can significantly improve the resistance to hydrothermal aging of redox property of the 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu catalyst. 3.2.3 EPR results Fig. 5 shows the EPR spectra of dehydrated samples recorded at 125 K. Compared with Cu-SSZ-13-F, the EPR signal intensity of 0.075Ce-Cu-F was slightly lower, which may be attributed to the fact that Ce cations can occupy part of the cation exchange sites [13], resulting in a slight decrease in the number of isolated Cu2+-2Z. After a small amount of Zr was introduced, the EPR signal intensity of 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-F was only slightly decreased, which may be due to the incorporation of some copper ions into the vacancies of Zirconia, forming a coordinated, oxygen-terminated surface structure [39], or a partial conversion of Cu2+ to Cu+ proved by the H2-TPR results. Interestingly, after hydrothermal aging, the signal intensity of the CeZr co-doping catalyst was significantly enhanced compared with their corresponding fresh samples, which may be attributed to the partial conversion of [Cu(OH)] +-Z species to Cu2+-2Z [7,8], the generation of CuAl2O4 species [41], and the migration of free Cu2+ species to the exchange site [33]. Additionally, 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A had lower EPR signal intensity compared to 0.075Ce-Cu-A, indicator of less CuAl2O4 species and Cu2+-2Z. In fact, it should be noted that the framework of 0.075Ce-Cu-A was more severely damaged after aging compared with 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A, resulting in more extra-framework Al. Under severe hydrothermal aging conditions, many active Cu2+ may convert to CuOx species, and the movement of CuOx species consequently accelerate the framework dealumination [7,19,42]. And it has been reported that Zr has an ability to trap CuOx as a stable phase and inhibit the movement of CuOx by forming CuOx-ZrO2 [23]. Overall, combined with the H2-TPR results, it is reasonable to infer that Zr doping can alleviate the attack of CuOx species to the zeolite framework, hamper the generation of extra-framework Al, thereby form less CuAl2O4 species and inhibit the transfer of free Cu2+ to exchange sites. Combined with the above SEM, XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption and NH3-TPD results, it can be concluded that appropriate Ce-Zr co-doping can well stabilize the SSZ-13 framework and disperse active Cu species, alleviate the generation of CuOx and CuAl2O4 species. So it is reasonable to propose that an appropriate co-doping of Zr and Ce can increase the number of Cu+ in the center of the hexagonal prism at the expense of part of the active Cu2+, which can boost the redox cycle, and consequently accelerate the NH3-SCR reaction. 3.3 Catalytic performance Fig. 6 (a) and (b) show the NOx conversion plots for the fresh and aged Cu-SSZ-13 and XCe-Cu catalysts. It can be observed that introducing a certain amount of Ce can significantly enhance the fresh NOx removal efficiency of Cu-SSZ-13, especially the low temperature SCR activity at below 200°C, which may be attributed to the reason that Ce can improve the redox property [9,14,19]. After hydrothermal aging at 800 °C for 16 h, the Ce modified samples with various Ce contents still retained more than 95% NOx conversion within 200-500 °C (Fig. 6 (b)). Compared with Cu-SSZ-13-A, Ce doping significantly enhanced the high temperature SCR activity at above 500°C, and the low temperature deNOx performance was also promoted to some extent, especially for 0.075Ce-Cu-A with optimal catalytic ability, its NOx removal efficiency at 175 °C was enhanced from 75% to 82% compared with Cu-SSZ-13-A. The results indicate that appropriate Ce doping is beneficial to the improvement of the hydrothermal stability of Cu-SSZ-13. Additionally, low Zr doping ratio (lower than 0.15) had little impact on the fresh low temperature SCR activity and slightly enhanced the high temperature deNOx ability (Fig. 6 (c)). But when the Zr doping ratio was higher than 0.15, the low temperature NOx conversion efficiency was slightly depressed by 3% compared with 0.075Ce-Cu, suggesting that Zr doping has no obvious impact on the fresh catalytic activity of 0.075Ce-Cu. After hydrothermal aging, the low temperature deNOx activity of the aged 0.075Ce-Cu (0.075Ce-Cu-A) was further improved by Zr doping (Fig. 6 (d)). Especially when the Zr doping ratio reached 0.25, the Zr modified 0.075Ce-Cu displayed the optimal resistance ability to hydrothermal aging. Specifically, compared with 0.075Ce-Cu-A, the NOx conversion of 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A at 140 °C-175 °C was increased by about 10%, and the high temperature deNOx efficiency at 550 °C was also enhanced by 6%. Even compared with the existing literature (Table S4), the aged catalyst 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A in this study still exhibited highly attractive denitrification activity, thanks to the subtle modification design using Ce and Zr. These results suggest that the co-doping of Ce and Zr can slightly improve the fresh SCR activity of Cu-SSZ-13, but significantly promote the resistance ability to hydrothermal aging. The N2O yields over the serial fresh and aged samples during the NH3-SCR reaction is shown in Fig. S3. Clearly, Ce doping and Ce\Zr co-doping have almost negligible impact on the N2O formation. After aging, the N2O yields was slightly enhanced compared with their corresponding fresh samples, possibly due to the generation of CuOx particles and collapse of zeolite framework deprived from the aging treatment. But, it can be observed that the N2O yields over co-doping of Ce and Zr samples were significantly lower than that of the Ce/Zr-free Cu-SSZ-13-A sample, evidencing that an appropriate co-doping of Ce and Zr is beneficial for the suppressing of the formation of CuOx clusters. Additionally, it should be noted that the N2O yields of all the samples in the temperature range of 100-550 °C is always lower than 8 ppm even after hydrothermal aging, suggesting the serial catalysts has a superior N2 selectivity. In order to deeply investigate the kinetic property, a kinetic experiment was conducted for the fresh and aged samples, the obtained Arrhenius plots are presented in Fig. 7 , for the fresh samples, the Ea values increased in the order of 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-F (31.90 kJ mol−1) < 0.075Ce-Cu-F (35.11 kJ mol−1) < Cu-SSZ-13-F (37.53 kJ mol−1), which is in good agreement with the increasing sequence of low temperature SCR activity of all fresh catalysts, signifying that an appropriate co-doping of Ce and Zr possessed the reduced reaction energy barrier couple with a higher reaction rate. After hydrothermal aging, the Ea values increased compared with their corresponding fresh sample, and the trend is consistence with the fresh samples, which is consistence with the activity results. And the reduction values of Ea is followed the order of 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-F (40.64 kJ mol−1) < 0.075Ce-Cu-F (45.19 kJ mol−1) < Cu-SSZ-13-F (50.51 kJ mol−1), underscoring the key role of an appropriate co-doping of Ce and Zr on the catalytic performance. In order to further verify its applicability of 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu catalyst in the actual diesel vehicle after-treatment system, the measurement of resistance ability to high space velocity over fresh and aged 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu catalyst was also evaluated at different GHSV. As is shown in Fig. S4, the fresh sample displayed a good overall anti high space velocity ability, and the NOx conversion efficiency could maintain more than 80% in the temperature range from 250 °C to 550 °C at a considerable high GHSV being 300,000 h−1 after hydrothermal aging, signifying its good adaptability. In summary, co-doping of Ce and Zr with an appropriate doping ratio can slightly enhance the fresh deNOx activity and effectively improve the resistance ability to hydrothermal aging of the catalyst Cu-SSZ-13, making the optimized 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu catalyst promising for the practical application of diesel NOx purification. 3.4 NH3-SCR reaction behavior 3.4.1 Reactivity of adsorbed NH3 species Fig. 8 shows the in-situ DRIFTS spectra of NH3 adsorption on fresh, aged samples of 0.075Ce-Cu and 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu at 175°C. The bands at 1530 and 1884 cm−1 are attributed to NH3 absorbed on the Lewis acid sites related to Cu sites, forming -NH3, -NH2 and -NH species [38,43]. Two IR bands at 1700 and 3602 cm−1 are assigned to NH4 + adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites linked to Al-O-NH4 + [44]. The bands at 3183, 3266 and 3336 cm−1 are assigned to the N-H stretching vibration modes [34,45,46]. In detail, the band at 3183 cm−1 is corresponded to the NH3 bound to Cu+ sites. The bands recorded at 3336 and 3266 cm−1 can be assigned to the NH4 + on terminal hydroxyl Si-OH and NH4 + ion on bridge hydroxyl Si-OH-Al, respectively [47,48]. Meanwhile, the band at 3655 cm−1 is corresponded to the NH4 + adsorbed on Si-OH [49]. It can be observed that the band at 1530 cm−1 assigned to the Lewis acid sites is slightly weakened after aging, possibly related to the reduction of isolated Cu2+, which is supported by the previous H2-TPR and EPR results. However, two new bands appear at 3675 and 2900 cm−1, which may be attributed to Zr-generated -OH groups (Zr-OH) and Lewis acid sites (eg, ZrOx, Zr4+), respectively [25]. Taking NH3-TPD results into consideration, the NH3 desorption peaks at medium and high temperatures after the introduction of Zr are not weakened with the reduction of isolated Cu2+, but significantly enhanced, proving that Zr doping can promote the production of L acidity. Importantly, after hydrothermal aging, the IR peaks assigned to L acid sites related to Cu sites over both 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu and 0.075Ce-Cu are also enhanced compared with their corresponding fresh samples [50]. Furthermore, it can be observed that 0.075Ce-Cu-A contains more L acid sites related to Cu sites than 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A, which is consistent with the NH3-TPD results. The above results again prove that Ce/Zr co-doping would significantly impact the coordination environment of Cu species during hydrothermal aging. In order to better compare the reaction behavior of isolated Cu species, the IR at 860-1000 cm−1 of fresh and aged samples after NH3 adsorption saturation is selected for analysis. As is shown in Fig. S5, two obvious peaks centered at ∼ 950 and ∼ 900 cm−1 can be observed on the two samples, which are attributed to Cu(OH)+-Z next to 8MR and Cu2+-2Z next to 6MR, respectively [51]. It can be observed that 0.075Ce-Cu possesses more Cu2+-2Z and Cu(OH)+-Z than 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu, which well agrees with the results of H2-TPR and EPR. After hydrothermal aging, the intensity of peaks attributed to Cu(OH)+-Z and Cu2+-2Z species does not decrease, but increase significantly. Based on this phenomenon, it can be speculated that the migration and transformation of Cu species occurs during hydrothermal aging, such as the conversion of [Cu(OH)] +-Z species to Cu2+-2Z or the migration of free Cu to ion exchange sites. However, the number of 8RM Cu does not decrease but increase significantly after aging, so the conversion of [Cu(OH)] +-Z species to Cu2+-2Z may be not the main factor. Considering EPR analysis supposed that some free Cu species can enter the vacancies derived from the framework dealumination, it is reasonable to believe that the increase in the number of isolated Cu2+ in 0.075Ce-Cu after hydrothermal aging can be attributed to the reason that the free Cu occupied the vacancies. In addition, the mobility of free state Cu during aging over 0.075Ce-Cu is significantly higher than that of 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu (Fig. S6), inferring that the degree of dealumination over 0.075Ce-Cu during aging is significantly more serious than that of 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu. The above results again confirm that CeZr co-doping has a certain promotion effect on stabilizing the zeolite framework structure during hydrothermal aging. After NH3 pre-adsorbed, NO + O2 was injected to the NH3 saturated sample. As is shown in Fig. 9(a) , the band region at 900 cm−1 (ammonia adsorbed on the Cu active site) almost disappears within 16 min. But the Brønsted acid sites (at 1448 cm−1) is more stable than Lewis acid sites, and it just declines slightly in 16 min, indicating that both NH3 species adsorbed on Lewis acid sites and NH4 + species generated at Bronsted acid sites participate in the NH3-SCR reaction. And NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites are significantly more reactive than NH4 + ions generated on Bronsted acid sites, which is consistent with other study [36]. Surprisingly, the band at 1613 cm−1 increases gradually over 30 min. It has been reported that the bands at 1610-1633 cm−1 can be assigned to the adsorbed NO2 species and bridge nitrate in the metal ion-exchanged zeolite [36,41]. Therefore, it is reasonable to infer that the band at 1613 cm−1 is assigned to the overlap of adsorbed NO species, bridging nitrate and Lewis acid sites. After the introduction of Zr, all bands do not change significantly within 4 min. But the bands at 2900 cm−1 begin to change, which is attributed to the consumption of NH3 on Lewis acid sites (like ZrOx, Zr4+). Comparing Fig. 9 (a) and (b), it can be obtained that NH3 on Lewis acid sites related to Cu sites in 0.075Ce-Cu is more active than that in 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu, which may be one of the important reasons why its fresh deNOx activity was not promoted after Zr doping. After hydrothermal aging, the bands at 1445 and 3275 cm−1 attributed to vibrations of hydroxy groups coordinated by NO+ [52,53] still do not appear after the introduction of NO + O2 gas for 40 min, as shown in Fig. 9 (c) and (d), it can be attributed to the migration and transformation of active Cu species, such as the migration of free-state Cu to ion-exchange sites or the generation of CuOx species, which is consistent with the H2-TPR and EPR results. However, the change in Cu coordination environment leads to a poor NH3 reactivity on Cu active sites and easier accumulation of NH4NO3 species (eg. 1448 cm−1) [54]. And the accumulation of NH4NO3 can be explained by the following two reaction equations. Some CuOx species will form after aging, which can enhance the adsorption of NO2 [55]. And NO2 will react with NH3 on B acid (NH3 adsorbed onto Brønsted acid sites) to generate NH4NO3, as is shown in reaction (1) [56]. With the continuous introduction of NO, NH4NO3 will be gradually consumed as in reaction (2). When the rate of reaction (1) is faster than that of reaction (2), NH4NO3 will accumulate on the surface and block the pores, thereby inhibiting the reaction cycle [57]. Therefore, the phenomenon of NH4NO3 clogging occurs in the aged catalyst, which is the main reason for its decrease in activity after hydrothermal aging. (1) 2 N O 2 + 2 N H 3 → N 2 + N H 4 N O 3 + 2 H 2 O (2) NO + N H 4 N O 3 → N O 2 + N 2 + H 2 O Interestingly, as shown in Fig. 10 , the peak area related to NH4NO3 in 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A is smaller than 0.075Ce-Cu-A, and the growth rate of peak area with reaction time is smaller. Therefore, it is reasonable to speculate that 0.075Ce-Cu-A is easier to accumulate NH4NO3 species than 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A, and it also indicates that 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A contains fewer CuOx species and B acid sites, which is consistent with the NH3-TPD and H2-TPR results. And this may be one of the important reasons why 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A is more active at low temperatures than 0.075Ce-Cu-A. Overall, the introduction of Zr can not only enhance the dispersion of Cu species and reduce the production of CuOx species, thereby inhibiting the accumulation of NH4NO3. In order to compare the reactivity of adsorbed NH3 on the active Cu, the IR of 0.075Ce-Cu-A and 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A at 875-975 cm−1 in Fig. S7 are selected for analysis. The 900 and 950 cm−1 bands are induced by Cu2+ in D6R and [Cu(OH)] + in the CHA cage, respectively [58,59]. Clearly, [Cu(OH)] + and Cu2+ are more abundant in 0.075Ce-Cu-A according to previous characterizations. After the introduction of NO + O2, the NH3 connected to the Cu species is gradually consumed, and the band at 950 cm−1 weakens faster than that at 900 cm−1 (almost disappeared after 20 min), suggesting that [Cu(OH)] + is more reactive at low temperature than Cu2+ in D6R. Notably, the NH3 connected to [Cu(OH)] + on 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A is almost disappeared within 20min (Fig. S7), while some NH3 still exists in 0.075Ce-Cu-A at 20min, and it can be observed that 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A consumes more NH3 than 0.075Ce-Cu-A after reaching the stable reaction state (Fig. S8), which means that Zr doping could significantly promote the NH3 activation after hydrothermal aging. Combined with the H2-TPR results, it can be reasonably deduced that the better redox property derived from containing more active Cu species is an important reason of its better catalytic activity over 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A than that of 0.075Ce-Cu-A. From another point of view, the better the reactivity of the [Cu(OH)] + in 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A, the faster the reaction of NOx and NH3 on active Cu, which can reduce the rates at which NOx combines with NH3 on B acid sites to generate NH4NO3 species. Therefore, it is reasonable to propose that holding more reactive [Cu(OH)] + species is an important reason for the improved catalytic ability over 0.075Ce0.25ZrCu-A. 3.4 Reactivity of adsorbed NOx species After the end of the previous step of feeding NO, purging for 5 min and then introducing 500 ppm of NH3, and the results are shown in Fig. 11(a) and (b). After the introduction of NH3 into 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-F, the surface nitrate and nitrite species are almost consumed within 3 min and the latter peaks are resulted from the formation of NH3 coordinated to Lewis acid sites and NH4 + adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites linked to Al-O-NH4 +. Regardless, the band intensities at 900, 950 cm−1 do not change much, implying that only a small amount of nitrite and nitrate species are present on the active Cu sites, which is consistent with what is seen in Fig. 11(b). After hydrothermal aging, it can be clearly observed that the band strengths of the two catalysts at 900 and 950 cm−1 weaken rapidly within 3 min (Fig. 11), and then gradually increase, which can be attributed to the consumption of nitrite and nitrate on the Cu site and NH3 adsorption. Therefore, it is reasonable to infer that the NH3-SCR reaction in the Ce/Zr-Cu-SSZ-13 system follows the "Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H)" mechanism. Notably, the band at 1448 cm−1 associated with NH4NO3 species gradually weakens until it disappears at 11 min, which can be attributed to the decomposition of NH4NO3, as shown in (3) [60,61]. (3) N H 4 N O 3 → N 2 O + 2 H 2 O In conclusion, the introduction of Zr does not change the reaction mechanism of 0.075Ce-Cu, but brings more acid sites and enhances the reactivity of the [Cu(OH)]+, and reducing the production of CuOx species, thereby inhibiting the accumulation of NH4NO3 species, resulting in better low-temperature activity. 3.5 Possible promoting mechanism of Zr doping to enhance hydrothermal stability Through a comprehensive analysis of the above characterizations, a plausible mechanism for Zr and Ce doping to enhance hydrothermal stability is proposed and demonstrated in Scheme 1 . The co-doping of Zr and Ce can stabilize the zeolite structure, specifically, a part of ZrO2 species can capture the CuOx generated during the aging process and inhibit the movement of CuOx in the pores, thereby mitigating the damage to the framework structure. Therefore, even under severe hydrothermal aging at 800°C, 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A still maintains a relatively complete framework structure with a large proportion of active Cu. In addition, co-doping of Zr and Ce is also beneficial to enhance the redox property and promote the SCR reaction cycle, improve the reactivity of the [Cu(OH)]+ and NH3 activation, and accelerate the decomposition of NH4NO3, which is consequently responsible for the promotion of the aged catalytic ability. 4 Conclusion A series of CeZr/Cu-SSZ-13 composite zeolite catalysts were synthesized by using commercial H-SSZ-13 as the carrier, ion-exchanged with Ce and Cu, then impregnated with Zr. The characterization results suggest that the introduction of Zr and Ce has a distinct effect on the framework stability, acidity, redox property. XRD, SEM and N2 adsorption results show that the zeolite structure remains intact after the introduction of Zr, but the crystallinity decreases slightly. During the hydrothermal aging process, appropriate Zr\Ce co-doping can well stabilize the framework structure, and excessive doping will make the cubic crystal part collapse. Appropriate Zr\Ce co-doping not only brings more acid sites, but also promotes the interaction of active metals with the zeolite framework, fortifies the dispersion of active Cu species and significantly boosts the redox ability and the SCR reaction cycle after aging. Meanwhile, Appropriate Zr\Ce co-doping can alleviate the generation of CuOx and CuAl2O4 species during the hydrothermal aging process. In addition, 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu-A had less NH4NO3 salt accumulation in the SCR reaction cycle, which is beneficial to the improvement of low-temperature SCR activity. The NH3-SCR reaction over the prepared Ce-Cu and Ce-Zr-Cu catalysts follows L-H mechanism. Among these catalysts, 0.075Ce0.25Zr-Cu showed the optimal catalytic performance. It exhibits excellent SCR activity over a wide temperature window of 175-550°C, as well as strong hydrothermal stability. This study provides a facile strategy for designing high-performance and robust Cu-CHA catalysts for the elimination of diesel NOx. coredata.dc:description: Promotion of the hydrothermal stability of Cu-CHA catalyst is a huge challenge. Metal modification is one of the important methods to improve the hydrothermal stability of Cu-CHA, but deeply insight into the roles of doped metal during the hydrothermal process is still lacking. In this study, a Ce-Zr/Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst was designed, and its robustness was significantly enhanced by adjusting the Ce and Zr doping ratios compared to Cu-SSZ-13. It was found that introducing a certain amount of Ce into Cu-SSZ-13 could enhance the redox property and stabilizing the framework structure. Nevertheless, the ability of Ce to stabilize the framework was still limited because the structure would be severely damaged during hydrothermal aging due to the movement of CuOx clusters generated in the cage. But, interestingly, an appropriate Ce-Zr co-doping could generate new hydroxyl components and acid sites, and inhibit the migration and agglomeration of isolated Cu ions during hydrothermal aging, which could significantly alleviate the formation of CuOx and CuAl2O4 species, thus promoting the stability of the as-gained catalyst. Additionally, an appropriate Ce-Zr co-doping could also restrain the accumulation of intermediate product NH4NO3 in the low temperature NH3-SCR reaction after hydrothermal aging, resulting in an enhanced low-temperature SCR ability over the aged catalyst. This work can be used to assist in the design of the high-efficient diesel Cu-CHA catalyst, thus highlighting its remarkable potential for industrial applications.

coredata.dc:title: Understanding the roles of Ce and Zr on a Ce-Zr/Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst with improved hydrothermal stability for NOx reduction by NH3
